Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Situation2: They provide in-depth guidance on a critical task where mistakes could have serious consequences.
Story: My phone buzzed for the third time in ten minutes, my mother’s name lighting up the screen. I knew she was waiting for my usual lunchtime update—she liked to hear about my day, and I always tried to respond quickly, sharing little details to reassure her. But right now, I was sitting across from Maya, my mentee, who was anxiously awaiting my feedback on her project proposal. The stakes were high; a single oversight could derail weeks of work, and she needed my full attention and expertise. I could see the uncertainty in her eyes, and I wanted to be the mentor she deserved—present, thoughtful, and thorough. Yet, the guilt gnawed at me as my mother’s messages piled up, each one a silent reminder of the closeness we’d built through our daily conversations. I felt torn, my mind pulled in two directions, each role demanding something I couldn’t give at the same time. My fingers hovered over my phone, heart pounding, as I wrestled with which part of myself to honor in this moment.
